title: The LORD's Controversy
shortSummary: Micah 6 presents God's legal case against Israel, reminding them of His past faithfulness and calling them to genuine repentance. The chapter contrasts empty ritual sacrifices with the true requirements of God: justice, mercy, and humility before Him.
timeline: c. 750 BC - Ministry of the prophet Micah during the reigns of Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah of Judah

keyCharacters.name: Micah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet delivering God's message of indictment and call to repentance to Israel and Judah.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader God sent to deliver Israel from Egypt, mentioned as a reminder of God's past acts of salvation.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: Brother of Moses and Israel's first high priest, representing God's appointed leadership.

keyCharacters.name: Miriam
keyCharacters.description: Sister of Moses and Aaron, noted for her role in Israel's deliverance and worship.

keyCharacters.name: Balak
keyCharacters.description: King of Moab who sought to curse Israel, illustrating God's protection and righteousness.

keyCharacters.name: Balaam
keyCharacters.description: Prophet who was hired to curse Israel but instead blessed them, demonstrating God's sovereign righteousness.

definitions.definition: A legal dispute or case; here it refers to God's formal accusation against Israel for their unfaithfulness.
A sacrificial offering completely consumed by fire, symbolizing atonement and dedication to God.
The quality of being morally right or justifiable; God's standard of holy conduct.
Dishonest measures used in commerce, symbolizing injustice and corruption condemned by God.
Refers to the sinful practices and policies established by King Omri of Israel, which led to idolatry and judgment.

outline.heading: God's Legal Plea Against Israel
outline.description: God summons the mountains as witnesses to His dispute with Israel, reminding them of His past deliverance and faithfulness through Moses and the protection against Balak and Balaam.

outline.heading: The Futility of Empty Sacrifices
outline.description: Israel questions what offerings might please God, listing extravagant sacrifices, but God implies that external rituals alone cannot satisfy Him.

outline.heading: God’s True Requirements
outline.description: The prophet declares what God truly desires: justice, mercy, and humble walking with Him, emphasizing ethical living over ritual.

outline.heading: Condemnation of Social Injustice
outline.description: God denounces dishonest business practices, violence, lies, and deceit prevalent among Israel’s leaders and people.

outline.heading: Consequences of Sin
outline.description: God warns of judgment and desolation due to persistent sin, including the adoption of evil practices from Israel’s northern kings Omri and Ahab.

application: Examine your life for genuine obedience to God’s commands, focusing on justice, mercy, and humility rather than mere religious rituals.
Reject dishonest practices and speak truthfully in all your dealings as a reflection of God’s holiness.
Remember God’s faithfulness in your life as motivation to live in humble dependence and gratitude toward Him.
Trust that God’s requirements are not burdensome but lead to a life pleasing to Him and beneficial to others.

keyVerses.text: He hath shewed thee, O man, what is good; and what doth the LORD require of thee, but to do justly, and to love mercy, and to walk humbly with thy God?
keyVerses.significance: This verse succinctly summarizes God’s moral expectations for His people, emphasizing character over ritual.

keyVerses.text: For I brought thee up out of the land of Egypt, and redeemed thee out of the house of servants; and I sent before thee Moses, Aaron, and Miriam.
keyVerses.significance: A reminder of God’s past deliverance and covenant faithfulness, calling Israel to remember His grace.

keyVerses.text: Wherewith shall I come before the LORD, and bow myself before the high God? shall I come before him with burnt offerings, with calves of a year old?
keyVerses.significance: Highlights Israel’s misguided focus on external sacrifices rather than inward repentance and obedience.
